name: 2-methyl-1-heptene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The base structure for this compound is ethylene (ethene), which has a melting point of −169.2°C. The 2-methyl-1-heptene molecule consists of an ethylene base with additional alkyl groups attached. Each methyl group typically raises the melting point by about 20 degrees since it increases the van der Waals forces due to increased surface area and mass. However, as this compound has a long alkyl chain, the consistent incremental increase from each methylene (CH2) unit may not be as significant as a singular methyl group, so the effect is considered to be around 5 degrees per CH2 unit, since such long chains can increase the flexibility and reduce the overall impact on melting point increment. There are six additional methylene (CH2) units in the main chain, contributing to the increase in the melting point. There's also an additional methyl group branching at the second carbon, which increases the melting point, but as a branch point, it can also slightly disrupt the orderly packing of molecules, potentially lessening the effect of raising the melting point. Taking the presence of the double bond into consideration, which can increase rigidity and thus might have a minimal impact on raising the melting point in aliphatic hydrocarbons, its effect is considered negligible in this case.
Test (Predicted reason):
The base unit for 2-methyl-1-heptene is heptane, which has a melting point of -95.7°C. The addition of a methyl group to the heptane chain typically increases the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. We can estimate this increase to be around +20°C.
